And as anybody who knows

155.07.text:
But I decided the only way

158.29.text:
was to get the whole village
where I live to make it with me.

162.45.text: I live in a small village in Oxfordshire.

164.45.text:
We have a few houses, some nice farms,
and a little stately home in the middle.

169.20.text:
And so, one evening
I went out into the village,

172.10.text:
and I put these posters
all over the village, and they said:

182.54.text: I called a meeting at the village hall,

184.42.text:
and I thought no one
is going to turn up at all,

186.76.text:
but that village hall
was absolutely packed.

189.40.text:
I learned the first thing
about outrageous optimism,

193.11.text:
that if you share your dream,
people will come.

197.18.text: The village started to get to work.

199.32.text: We knew three things about Hollywood.

201.28.text: We knew it's not about the art,

203.07.text: it's about power, money, and sex.

207.28.text:
And in Kingston Bagpuize, in Oxforshire,
we don't have any of those.

212.62.text: We don't have any of those,

213.93.text:
so the only way we were
going to get them was by asking,

217.87.text: The first thing we needed was power.

219.90.text:
The power in Kingstone Bagpuize
is the parish council,

222.50.text:
they decide what happens in the village
and what doesn't happen.

229.40.text:
practicing for the village fate,
so, obviously,

231.77.text:
they're the right kind of people,

234.86.text:
I thought: "Well, this asking

237.67.text:
so I'll move up the food chain
and I'll ask our MP."

241.31.text: This is him shortly after I asked him.

244.98.text:
I said: "We are making a film
in the village with 2000 of your voters.

254.25.text:
Funny enough, he did.
His name is Ed.

256.89.text:
I learned something
also about asking people.

261.08.text:
First of all, people in power
are just people like us,

263.86.text:
normal people
with slightly bigger offices,

268.63.text:
people in power are often
as surprised as you are

276.99.text:
So don't ever hesitate
to ask them anything.

284.20.text:
We asked the people we knew,
and they asked people they knew.

287.30.text: We unleashed the power of social media,

290.34.text:
which in Kingstone Bagpuize means
putting a little note up the bus stop,

295.54.text: and then we raised the money.

297.26.text:
We didn't raise a huge amount
of money, but we raised enough.

301.02.text:
What was really important
is the money we didn't spend.

304.24.text:
And the money we didn't spend
was on two things:

307.21.text:
it was on accommodation 
and hotels, and it was on catering

311.25.text:
because they cost 
a fortune in making a film.

314.23.text: Instead, I went to the Women's Institute,

318.92.text:
and I said: "Would you mind
doing the catering for the film?"

323.27.text:
We'll do a few scones,
and we'll use the big teapot."

327.95.text:
It turned out in the end
they catered for up to 60 people,

336.06.text: and that is a hell of a teapot.

339.40.text:
The most wonderful thing
was [that] a woman came to me,

342.02.text: she's not on that photo, and she said:

343.92.text:
"Guy, I know nothing about film,
but I do know about making fairy cakes,

347.31.text:
I'm going to make you
a thousand fairy cakes."

349.65.text: That's what she did, and here they are —

We didn't spend any money

357.35.text:
because all the professional
cast and crew,

363.76.text:
In fact, some of them are still there,

367.52.text: So, we had the money, we had the power,

369.92.text: and the last thing we needed was the sex.

371.89.text:
We wanted to do a romantic comedy,
so we needed somebody good-looking,

375.28.text:
and, sadly, there are no good looking
people in Kingstone Bagpuize,

379.10.text:
apart from the Women's Institute,
obviously, just making that clear.

385.12.text: I had a friend, and he said he knew

387.31.text:
a very good-looking guy
who lived in London.

389.44.text:
I thought: "Well, if he lives in London,
he must be attractive!"

394.51.text:
Here he is, Tom Mitchelson,
and he's a very great-looking guy.

398.09.text: I had lunch with him and I said:

400.56.text:
"Would you like to be
the star in our film?"

402.78.text:
He said yes immediately,
and he told me afterwards

405.22.text:
he just wanted to get out
of the restaurant as quickly as possible,

409.41.text: because there is a very fine line

411.35.text:
between being an outrageous optimist

418.75.text:
is when you're outrageously optimistic,
people often say yes

421.76.text:
because they don't believe

425.09.text: and when it does, it's too late.

437.77.text:
When the whole community works together

and I sat down to edit

and I've promised the whole village

479.83.text: But the thing about outrageous optimism

483.26.text:
is that it works best
when things are at their bleakest.

485.96.text:
I didn't know how we
are going to move forward,

488.54.text:
but I was sure that the universe
would provide some way of moving forward.

492.26.text: What the universe provided, was a woman,

494.57.text: a very special woman called Beverly Mills.

497.25.text:
She had seen this 4-hour epic,
and she said to me:

499.71.text:
"Guy, you've got a good film
in there, but that's not it."

505.58.text: I listened to her very, very carefully,

507.50.text:
because she was and is

510.83.text:
and she reedited our entire film
for nothing, between Hollywood epics,

514.96.text: and I didn't even have to ask her.

517.46.text:
The wonderful thing was she gave us
this fantastic 90-minute film

522.50.text:

531.03.text: one, I could emigrate to Canada,

So, right then and there,
in Leicester Square,

I got my phone out,

564.31.text: They answered the phone and I said:

565.99.text:

you'll need to reopen it,

569.01.text:
you'll need to celebrate
the reopening it,

574.45.text:

580.39.text:
driving their tractors

583.93.text:

They thought about it

and then something

595.94.text: [that] is that our friendly MP, Ed,

When that happens,

we took the village

This is our village in the cinema,

654.34.text:
is there's a lady in the back

673.83.text:
about outrageous optimism
in that whole project.

676.61.text:
The first thing I learned
was the absolute power of asking people,

680.79.text:
and I firmly believe that everybody
has a big yes inside them

685.74.text: that's just waiting to get out.

687.83.text:
The second thing I learned
with outrageous optimism,

690.74.text: is you can't do everything yourself.

693.21.text:
But, that if your roll 
the red carpet out for other people,

697.40.text: they'll roll the red carpet out for you.
